questions.question: A car accelerates uniformly from an initial velocity of $15\text{ m/s}$ to a final velocity of $40\text{ m/s}$ over a distance of $175\text{ m}$. Calculate the magnitude of the constant acceleration.
A cyclist traveling at a constant velocity of $20\text{ m/s}$ applies brakes and comes to a uniform stop in $10\text{ s}$. Calculate the distance covered by the cyclist while braking.
questions.explanation: Using $s = \frac{u+v}{2} \times t$: $s = \frac{20 + 0}{2} \times 10 = 10 \times 10 = 100\text{ m}$.

questions.question: A ball is dropped from rest and falls freely under gravity for a time of $4.5\text{ s}$. Neglecting air resistance, calculate the distance fallen. Use $g = 9.8\text{ m/s}^2$.

A ball is thrown vertically upward from hand level and returns to the thrower's hand $3.6\text{ s}$ later. Neglecting air resistance, calculate the magnitude of the initial upward velocity. Use $g = 9.8\text{ m/s}^2$.
questions.explanation: Time to reach maximum height is $1.8\text{ s}$. Using $v = u + at$ with $v = 0$ at the top: $0 = u - 9.8(1.8) \rightarrow u = 17.64 \approx 17.6\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A plane flying horizontally at a constant speed of $180\text{ km/h}$ at an altitude of $320\text{ m}$ drops a package. Neglecting air resistance, calculate the horizontal distance the package travels from its release point to the point of impact.
questions.explanation: Horizontal velocity: $v_x = 180/3.6 = 50\text{ m/s}$. Fall time: $320 = 4.9t^2 \rightarrow t = \sqrt{320/4.9} = \sqrt{65.31} = 8.08\text{ s}$. Horizontal distance: $d = v_x \times t = 50 \times 8.08 \approx 404\text{ m}$.

questions.question: A projectile is launched from ground level with an initial speed of $55\text{ m/s}$ at an angle of $60^{\circ}$ above the horizontal. Neglecting air resistance, calculate the total time of flight until the projectile returns to ground level.
questions.explanation: Time of flight: $T = \frac{2u\sin\theta}{g} = \frac{2(55)\sin(60^{\circ})}{9.8} = \frac{110 \times 0.866}{9.8} \approx 9.72\text{ s}$.

questions.question: Determine the maximum height reached by a projectile launched from ground level with an initial speed of $40\text{ m/s}$ at an angle of $45^{\circ}$ above the horizontal. Neglect air resistance.
questions.explanation: Vertical component of initial velocity: $u_y = 40\sin(45^{\circ}) = 40 \times 0.7071 = 28.28\text{ m/s}$. Maximum height: $h = \frac{u_y^2}{2g} = \frac{800}{19.6} \approx 40.8\text{ m}$.

questions.question: A boat heads directly across a river, pointing perpendicular to the banks, at a speed of $6.0\text{ m/s}$ relative to the water. The river current flows parallel to the banks at a speed of $5.0\text{ m/s}$. Calculate the magnitude of the boat's resultant velocity relative to an observer on the shore.
questions.explanation: The two velocity components are perpendicular: $v = \sqrt{(6.0)^2 + (5.0)^2} = \sqrt{36 + 25} = \sqrt{61} \approx 7.81\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: Car A travels due East at a constant speed of $110\text{ km/h}$ and Car B travels due North at a constant speed of $85\text{ km/h}$. Calculate the magnitude of the velocity of Car A as measured by an observer in Car B (i.e., the magnitude of the relative velocity of Car A with respect to Car B).
questions.explanation: The relative velocity vector has perpendicular components: $|\vec{v}_{A/B}| = \sqrt{110^2 + 85^2} = \sqrt{12100 + 7225} = \sqrt{19325} \approx 139\text{ km/h}$.

questions.question: A box of mass $35\text{ kg}$ is pulled across a horizontal surface by a horizontal force of $175\text{ N}$. If the box accelerates at $3.0\text{ m/s}^2$, calculate the coefficient of kinetic friction between the box and the surface.
questions.explanation: Net force: $F_{net} = ma = 35 \times 3.0 = 105\text{ N}$. Friction force: $f_k = F_{applied} - F_{net} = 175 - 105 = 70\text{ N}$. Coefficient of kinetic friction: $\mu_k = f_k/(mg) = 70/(35 \times 9.8) = 70/343 \approx 0.20$.

questions.question: A hockey puck of mass $1.6\text{ kg}$ slides across ice with an initial speed of $7.0\text{ m/s}$. If the coefficient of kinetic friction between the puck and the ice is $\mu_k = 0.35$, calculate the time it takes for the puck to slide to a stop.
questions.explanation: Deceleration due to friction: $a = -\mu_k g = -0.35 \times 9.8 = -3.43\text{ m/s}^2$. Using $v = v_0 + at$ with $v = 0$: $0 = 7.0 - 3.43t \rightarrow t = 7.0/3.43 \approx 2.04\text{ s}$.

questions.question: Calculate the magnitude of the impulse required to bring a car of mass $1400\text{ kg}$ traveling at a speed of $28\text{ m/s}$ to a complete stop.
questions.explanation: Impulse $J = \Delta p = m\Delta v = 1400(0 - 28) = -39200\text{ N·s}$. The magnitude is $3.92 \times 10^4\text{ N·s}$.

questions.question: A block of mass $18\text{ kg}$ rests on a frictionless incline that makes an angle of $45^{\circ}$ with the horizontal. Calculate the magnitude of the component of the block's weight that acts parallel to the surface of the incline.
questions.explanation: $F_{\parallel} = mg\sin\theta = (18)(9.8)\sin(45^{\circ}) = 176.4 \times 0.7071 \approx 124.7\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A block slides down a frictionless incline that makes an angle of $40^{\circ}$ with the horizontal. Starting from rest, calculate the time it takes for the block to travel a distance of $11\text{ m}$ along the incline.
questions.explanation: Acceleration down the incline: $a = g\sin\theta = 9.8\sin(40^{\circ}) = 9.8 \times 0.6428 = 6.30\text{ m/s}^2$. Using $s = \frac{1}{2}at^2$: $t = \sqrt{2s/a} = \sqrt{2 \times 11/6.30} = \sqrt{22/6.30} \approx 1.87\text{ s}$.

questions.question: In an Atwood machine, two masses, $M_1 = 10\text{ kg}$ and $M_2 = 14\text{ kg}$, are connected by a light string passing over a frictionless, massless pulley. Calculate the acceleration of the system when it is released from rest.

An $8.0\text{ kg}$ block on a horizontal table with coefficient of kinetic friction $\mu_k = 0.22$ is connected by a light string over a frictionless pulley to a $4.0\text{ kg}$ hanging mass. Calculate the tension in the string when the system is released.
A mass of $6.0\text{ kg}$ is suspended by two identical light strings, each making an angle of $60^{\circ}$ with the vertical. Calculate the tension in each string.
questions.explanation: Vertical equilibrium: $2T\cos(60^{\circ}) = mg = 6.0 \times 9.8 = 58.8\text{ N}$. Since $\cos(60^{\circ}) = 0.5$, we have $2T \times 0.5 = T = 58.8\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A person with a mass of $100\text{ kg}$ stands on a scale inside an elevator that is accelerating upward at $3.5\text{ m/s}^2$. What is the reading on the scale (the apparent weight of the person)?
questions.explanation: When accelerating upward, the apparent weight is $N = m(g + a) = 100(9.8 + 3.5) = 100 \times 13.3 = 1330\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A wheel of radius $0.50\text{ m}$ rotates at $1100\text{ rpm}$ (revolutions per minute). Assuming no slipping, calculate the linear speed of a point on the rim in $\text{m/s}$.
questions.explanation: Angular velocity: $\omega = 1100 \times 2\pi/60 = 1100 \times 0.10472 = 115.19\text{ rad/s}$. Linear speed: $v = \omega r = 115.19 \times 0.50 \approx 57.6\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: An object moving in uniform circular motion has a centripetal acceleration of $32\text{ m/s}^2$. If the radius of the circular path is $6.0\text{ m}$, calculate the frequency of rotation.
questions.explanation: Centripetal acceleration: $a_c = \omega^2 r \rightarrow \omega = \sqrt{a_c/r} = \sqrt{32/6.0} = \sqrt{5.333} = 2.309\text{ rad/s}$. Frequency: $f = \omega/(2\pi) = 2.309/6.28 \approx 0.37\text{ Hz}$.

questions.question: A mass of $1.0\text{ kg}$ is attached to a string and whirled in a vertical circle of radius $1.2\text{ m}$. If the speed of the mass at the bottom of the circle is $9.0\text{ m/s}$, calculate the tension in the string at that instant.
Calculate the maximum constant speed at which a car can travel over the crest of a circular hill with a radius of curvature of $65\text{ m}$ without losing contact with the road.
questions.explanation: At the point of losing contact, the normal force becomes zero and gravity provides the centripetal force: $mg = mv^2/r \rightarrow v = \sqrt{gr} = \sqrt{9.8 \times 65} = \sqrt{637} \approx 25.2\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A mass of $0.28\text{ kg}$ is whirled in a horizontal circle of radius $1.0\text{ m}$. If the tension in the string is $6.0\text{ N}$, calculate the speed of the mass.
questions.explanation: For horizontal circular motion, $T = mv^2/r \rightarrow v = \sqrt{Tr/m} = \sqrt{6.0 \times 1.0 / 0.28} = \sqrt{6.0/0.28} = \sqrt{21.43} \approx 4.63\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A curve on a highway has a radius of $120\text{ m}$ and is designed for a safe speed of $30\text{ m/s}$ with no friction required. Calculate the banking angle of the curve.
questions.explanation: For a banked curve with no friction, $\tan\theta = v^2/(rg) = (30)^2/(120 \times 9.8) = 900/1176 = 0.7653$. Therefore $\theta = \tan^{-1}(0.7653) \approx 37.4^{\circ}$.

questions.question: Calculate the distance between the centers of two objects, each of mass $1100\text{ kg}$, if the magnitude of the gravitational force of attraction between them is $3.5 \times 10^{-7}\text{ N}$. Use $G = 6.67 \times 10^{-11}\text{ N·m}^2/\text{kg}^2$.
questions.explanation: Using Newton's law of gravitation: $F = G\frac{m^2}{r^2} \rightarrow r^2 = G\frac{m^2}{F} = (6.67 \times 10^{-11})\frac{(1100)^2}{3.5 \times 10^{-7}} = (6.67 \times 10^{-11})\frac{1.21 \times 10^6}{3.5 \times 10^{-7}} = (6.67 \times 10^{-11})(3.457 \times 10^{12}) = 230.6$. Therefore $r = \sqrt{230.6} \approx 15.2\text{ m}$.

questions.question: A satellite orbits a planet in a circular orbit at a distance $R$ from the planet's center. If the satellite were moved to a new circular orbit at a distance $81R$ from the planet's center, by what factor would its orbital speed change?
questions.explanation: Orbital speed is given by $v = \sqrt{GM/r}$, so $v \propto 1/\sqrt{r}$. If the distance increases by a factor of $81$, the new speed factor is $1/\sqrt{81} = 1/9$.

questions.question: A block of mass $20\text{ kg}$ is pulled at a constant speed a distance of $18\text{ m}$ up a rough incline. If the constant kinetic friction force acting on the block is $26\text{ N}$, calculate the work done by the friction force on the block.
questions.explanation: Work done by friction is $W = -f_k d$, where the negative sign indicates that friction opposes the motion. Therefore $W = -(26)(18) = -468\text{ J}$.

questions.question: A ball of mass $0.18\text{ kg}$ is moving horizontally at a speed of $46\text{ m/s}$ when it is caught and stopped by a fielder. If the fielder's hand moves backward $0.55\text{ m}$ while stopping the ball, calculate the average force exerted by the ball on the hand.
questions.explanation: The initial kinetic energy is $KE = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 = 0.5 \times 0.18 \times (46)^2 = 0.5 \times 0.18 \times 2116 = 190.44\text{ J}$. This energy is dissipated as work done by the average force: $W = Fd \rightarrow F = W/d = 190.44/0.55 \approx 346\text{ N}$.

questions.question: Calculate the net work required to accelerate a car of mass $1900\text{ kg}$ from a speed of $20\text{ m/s}$ to a speed of $40\text{ m/s}$. Assume all work done goes into changing the kinetic energy.

A mass of $2.6\text{ kg}$ is fired vertically upward from a spring gun. The spring has a spring constant $k = 850\text{ N/m}$ and is compressed by $0.18\text{ m}$ before firing. Neglecting air resistance and the mass of the spring, calculate the maximum height reached by the mass above its launch point.
questions.explanation: The elastic potential energy stored in the spring is $PE_s = \frac{1}{2}kx^2 = 0.5 \times 850 \times (0.18)^2 = 425 \times 0.0324 = 13.77\text{ J}$. This converts to gravitational potential energy at the maximum height: $mgh = 13.77 \rightarrow h = 13.77/(2.6 \times 9.8) = 13.77/25.48 \approx 0.541\text{ m}$.

questions.question: A $9.0\text{ kg}$ block slides from rest down a frictionless ramp from a height of $5.5\text{ m}$. At the bottom of the ramp, it continues along a rough horizontal surface where friction brings it to a stop. If its speed at the very bottom of the ramp is measured to be $6.5\text{ m/s}$, calculate the amount of thermal energy generated due to friction on the horizontal surface.
questions.explanation: Initial gravitational potential energy: $PE_i = mgh = 9.0 \times 9.8 \times 5.5 = 485.1\text{ J}$. Kinetic energy at the bottom: $KE_f = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 = 0.5 \times 9.0 \times (6.5)^2 = 4.5 \times 42.25 = 190.1\text{ J}$. The energy lost to friction is $485.1 - 190.1 = 295.0\text{ J}$, which is converted to thermal energy.

questions.question: An electric motor with an efficiency of $78\%$ draws $1900\text{ W}$ of electrical power. At what constant speed can this motor lift a load of mass $80\text{ kg}$ vertically upward?
questions.explanation: Useful power output: $P_{out} = \text{efficiency} \times P_{in} = 0.78 \times 1900 = 1482\text{ W}$. For lifting at constant speed, $P_{out} = Fv = mgv$, so $v = P_{out}/(mg) = 1482/(80 \times 9.8) = 1482/784 \approx 1.89\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: Calculate the horsepower required to lift a load of mass $200\text{ kg}$ vertically upward a distance of $26\text{ m}$ in $13\text{ s}$. Use the conversion $1\text{ hp} = 746\text{ W}$.
questions.explanation: Work done: $W = mgh = 200 \times 9.8 \times 26 = 200 \times 254.8 = 50960\text{ J}$. Power: $P = W/t = 50960/13 = 3920\text{ W}$. Horsepower: $3920/746 \approx 5.26\text{ hp}$.

questions.question: A block of mass $2.6\text{ kg}$ moves horizontally at $7.5\text{ m/s}$ and collides with a light horizontal spring with spring constant $k = 1500\text{ N/m}$. Assuming no friction, calculate the maximum compression of the spring.
questions.explanation: The kinetic energy of the block converts to elastic potential energy in the spring: $\frac{1}{2}mv^2 = \frac{1}{2}kx^2 \rightarrow x = \sqrt{mv^2/k} = \sqrt{(2.6)(7.5)^2/1500} = \sqrt{(2.6)(56.25)/1500} = \sqrt{146.25/1500} = \sqrt{0.0975} \approx 0.312\text{ m}$.

questions.question: If $45\text{ J}$ of work is required to stretch a particular spring by $18\text{ cm}$ from its natural length, how much work (in J) is required to stretch it an additional $18\text{ cm}$ (i.e., from $18\text{ cm}$ to $36\text{ cm}$)?
questions.explanation: Work done on a spring is proportional to the square of the displacement: $W \propto x^2$. If $45\text{ J}$ stretches it by $18\text{ cm}$, then stretching it by $36\text{ cm}$ requires $45 \times (36/18)^2 = 45 \times 4 = 180\text{ J}$. The additional work from $18\text{ cm}$ to $36\text{ cm}$ is $180 - 45 = 135\text{ J}$.

questions.question: A car of mass $1800\text{ kg}$ moving at $22\text{ m/s}$ collides head-on and locks bumpers with a stationary truck of mass $2700\text{ kg}$. Assuming the collision is perfectly inelastic, calculate the final velocity of the combined wreck immediately after the collision.
questions.explanation: Conservation of momentum: $m_1v_1 + m_2v_2 = (m_1 + m_2)v_f$. Therefore $(1800)(22) + (2700)(0) = (4500)v_f \rightarrow v_f = 39600/4500 = 8.80\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: In a perfectly elastic head-on collision, a ball of mass $2.6\text{ kg}$ moving at $11\text{ m/s}$ strikes a stationary ball of mass $5.2\text{ kg}$. Calculate the final velocity of the $5.2\text{ kg}$ ball immediately after the collision.
questions.explanation: For an elastic collision where the target is initially at rest, the velocity of the target after collision is given by $v_2 = \frac{2m_1}{m_1+m_2}u_1 = \frac{2(2.6)}{7.8}(11) = \frac{5.2}{7.8}(11) = 0.6667 \times 11 \approx 7.33\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: An object of mass $1.2\text{ kg}$ initially at rest explodes into two pieces. One piece of mass $0.55\text{ kg}$ moves away at $26\text{ m/s}$. Calculate the kinetic energy of the other piece, which has a mass of $0.65\text{ kg}$, immediately after the explosion.
questions.explanation: By conservation of momentum: $0 = (0.55)(26) + (0.65)v_2 \rightarrow v_2 = -(14.3)/(0.65) = -22.0\text{ m/s}$ (the negative indicates opposite direction). The kinetic energy is $KE = \frac{1}{2}(0.65)(22.0)^2 = 0.325 \times 484 \approx 157\text{ J}$.

questions.question: A $24\text{ V}$ battery is connected in series with a $180\Omega$ resistor and a $260\Omega$ resistor. Calculate the voltage drop across the $180\Omega$ resistor.
questions.explanation: Total resistance: $R_{total} = 180 + 260 = 440\Omega$. Current: $I = V/R_{total} = 24/440 = 0.05455\text{ A}$. Voltage across $180\Omega$ resistor: $V = IR = 0.05455 \times 180 \approx 9.82\text{ V}$.

questions.question: Two resistors connected in series have a total equivalent resistance of $1120\Omega$. If the ratio of their individual resistances is $4:5$, find the resistance of the smaller resistor.
questions.explanation: Let the resistors be $4R$ and $5R$. Then $4R + 5R = 1120 \rightarrow 9R = 1120 \rightarrow R = 124.44$. The smaller resistor is $4R = 497.8 \approx 498\Omega$.

questions.question: Calculate the equivalent resistance of three resistors, each with a resistance of $270\Omega$, connected in parallel.
questions.explanation: For resistors in parallel: $\frac{1}{R_{eq}} = \frac{1}{270} + \frac{1}{270} + \frac{1}{270} = \frac{3}{270} = \frac{1}{90}$. Therefore $R_{eq} = 90\Omega$.

questions.question: Four identical resistors are connected in parallel. The equivalent resistance of this combination is $28\Omega$. Calculate the resistance of each individual resistor.
questions.explanation: For $n$ identical resistors in parallel, $R_{eq} = R/n$. Here $R_{eq} = R/4 = 28\Omega$, so $R = 4 \times 28 = 112\Omega$.

questions.question: A $55\Omega$ resistor is connected in parallel with another $55\Omega$ resistor. This parallel combination is then connected in series with a $28\Omega$ resistor. Calculate the total equivalent resistance of this circuit.
questions.explanation: The parallel combination: $R_p = \frac{1}{1/55 + 1/55} = \frac{55}{2} = 27.5\Omega$. Adding the series resistor: $R_{total} = 27.5 + 28 = 55.5\Omega$.

questions.question: A $22\text{ V}$ battery is connected to a circuit consisting of a $22\Omega$ resistor in series with a parallel combination of two $44\Omega$ resistors. Calculate the total power dissipated in the circuit.
questions.explanation: The parallel combination: $R_p = \frac{1}{1/44 + 1/44} = \frac{44}{2} = 22\Omega$. Total resistance: $R_{total} = 22 + 22 = 44\Omega$. Power: $P = V^2/R_{total} = (22)^2/44 = 484/44 = 11\text{ W}$.

questions.question: A wave travels a distance of $55\text{ m}$ in $11\text{ s}$. If the wavelength is $1.1\text{ m}$, calculate the frequency of the wave.
questions.explanation: Wave speed: $v = \text{distance}/\text{time} = 55/11 = 5.0\text{ m/s}$. Frequency: $f = v/\lambda = 5.0/1.1 \approx 4.55\text{ Hz}$.

questions.question: A string of length $2.0\text{ m}$ and total mass $5.5\text{ g}$ is under a tension of $120\text{ N}$. Calculate the fundamental frequency of vibration for this string.
questions.explanation: Linear mass density: $\mu = m/L = 0.0055/2.0 = 0.00275\text{ kg/m}$. Wave speed: $v = \sqrt{T/\mu} = \sqrt{120/0.00275} = \sqrt{43636} = 208.9\text{ m/s}$. Fundamental frequency: $f = v/(2L) = 208.9/(2 \times 2.0) = 208.9/4.0 \approx 52.2\text{ Hz}$.

questions.question: A person standing on a stationary platform hears the whistle of a train. The frequency heard as the train approaches is $850\text{ Hz}$, and the frequency heard as it recedes is $680\text{ Hz}$. Assuming the speed of sound is $v_s = 340\text{ m/s}$, calculate the speed of the train.
questions.explanation: Using the Doppler effect: $\frac{f_{approach}}{f_{recede}} = \frac{v_s + v}{v_s - v}$. Substituting: $\frac{850}{680} = \frac{340+v}{340-v} \rightarrow \frac{5}{4} = \frac{340+v}{340-v} \rightarrow 5(340-v) = 4(340+v) \rightarrow 1700 - 5v = 1360 + 4v \rightarrow 340 = 9v \rightarrow v \approx 37.8\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: Two speakers are separated by a distance of $5.4\text{ m}$ and emit a $740\text{ Hz}$ tone in phase. The speed of sound is $340\text{ m/s}$. At what distance from the center point along the line joining the two speakers is the first point of constructive interference located?
questions.explanation: Wavelength: $\lambda = v/f = 340/740 = 0.4595\text{ m}$. For constructive interference along the line between the speakers, the path difference is $\Delta = \lambda$ at the first antinode. If $x$ is the distance from the center, then $2x = \lambda \rightarrow x = \lambda/2 = 0.4595/2 \approx 0.230\text{ m}$.

questions.question: Calculate the length of a closed-end organ pipe (closed at one end, open at the other) that has a third harmonic frequency of $800.33\text{ Hz}$. Take the speed of sound as $v_s = 343\text{ m/s}$.
questions.explanation: For a closed pipe, the third harmonic frequency is $f_3 = 3v/(4L)$. Solving for length: $L = 3v/(4f_3) = 3(343)/(4 \times 800.33) = 1029/3201.3 \approx 0.321\text{ m}$.

questions.question: Two sound waves with frequencies of $650\text{ Hz}$ and $661\text{ Hz}$ interfere. Calculate the beat frequency heard.
questions.explanation: The beat frequency is the absolute difference between the two frequencies: $f_{beat} = |f_2 - f_1| = |661 - 650| = 11\text{ Hz}$.
